column1: Laghouat (English: Laghwat French: Laghouat Arabic: الأغواط‎) is the capital of the Laghouat Province
column2: Algeria
column3: 400 km (250 mi) south of the Algerian capital Algiers. Located in the Amour Range of the Saharan Atlas
column4: the town is an oasis on the north edge of the Sahara Desert. It is an important administrative and military center and marketplace
column5: and is known for rug and tapestry weaving.

column1: Laghouat traces its history to at least the 11th century. It paid tribute to Morocco in the 17th century and was captured by the Ottoman Turks in 1786.  The town experienced the brutal Siege of Laghouat in 1852
column2: and came under French colonial rule until 1962. Since 1974
column3: it has been the seat of a province of the same name.

column1: The population of the town was 126
column2: 291 inhabitants in 2005. There are natural gas deposits in the region
column3: and nearby Hassi R'Mel has the largest natural gas reserve in Africa. The city is served by Laghouat Airport.

column1: == Etymology ==
The city and the region as a whole were named by several titles
column2: including 'the capital of the steppe'
column5: and 'the city of the four seasons'.

column1: == Geography ==
The town of Laghouat is a regional center in the Algerian depression
column2: an oasis south of Algiers. It is built on the banks of the Wadi Mzee
column3: which flows eastwards from the Amour Range and is one of a large number of seasonal streams that empty into Chott Melrhir.

column1: It is bordered to the north by the municipality of Sidi Makhlouf
column2: to the west by Tadjemout and Kheneg
column3: to the east the municipality of El Assafia
column4: and to the south the municipality of Mekhareg.

== Climate ==

Laghouat has a cold desert climate (Köppen climate classification BWk). Rainfall is higher in winter than in summer. The average annual temperature in Laghouat is 17.4 °C (63.3 °F). About 176 mm (6.93 in) of precipitation falls annually. Rain falls irregularly
column2: with severe droughts in some years. Sand dunes may encroach upon the town from the north in drought years
column3: and have been countered with administrative buildings and a green belt of gardens around the city.

column1: The town relies on groundwater
column2: which is abundant due to a large underground dam in Tadjmout
column3: which is the largest of its kind in Africa and dates to the colonial period.  It is also known for its mineral water
column5: which has attracted investment from a Spanish bottler.

column1: == Demographics ==
Most residents of Laghouat Province trace their origins to Berbers and Arabs. The town had a population of 170
column2: 693 people

column1: == History ==
=== Early history ===
Rock paintings and other archeological evidence indicate that people were living in the area during the Stone Age
column2: from about 9
column3: 000 BC.  It is believed that climactic change displaced these prehistoric peoples
column4: as it later displaced Roman and Byzantine settlements. The town's location was noted in Roman records on a plateau called Tizgrarin. The inhabitants refused to submit to the Byzantines and convert to Christianity
column5: and resisted paying tribute or taxes to the empires which followed
column6: who sometimes called it a "rebel city".

column1: In the 14th century
column2: Ibn Khaldoun reported the existence of a walled town which housed a faction of the "laghouat" tribe (called laghouat-ksel )
column3: a branch of the Berber tribe of the Maghraouas. Over time
column4: the majority of these peoples migrated westward
column5: leaving only two factions in the city:  the Berber-descended Sargins and the Ahlaf ("alliance") clans of Arabs.  Various nomadic peoples also populated the town at times. The region was known to have interactions with the Ottoman Empire and the Moroccan sultan
column6: and fell under the domination of the Ottoman Empire c. 1727.

column1: === French occupation ===
Laghouat was a center of resistance against French colonial rule from 1831 under Sheikh Moussa Ibn Hassen El Misri. In 1852
column2: France launched a punative campaign to eradicate the resistance. The Siege of Laghouat began on 21 November and concluded with the storming of the town on 4 December. Several days of brutal massacres followed
column3: which included one of the first recorded uses of chemical weapons on civilians. About two-thirds of the population perished
column4: which became known locally as the Khalya (Arabic: emptiness). It also started a local tradition of protecting young boys from evil with an earring (then done to disguise them as girls).

column1: Other settlements quickly capitulated following the example set at Laghouat
column2: and the French used the town as a gateway for a land route to Sub-Saharan Africa

column1: During World War II
column2: the Laghouat prison camp held British and Commonwealth servicemen
column3: under the authority of Vichy France. The camp also held a large number of Jews who were described by the French authorities as Communists. Following the war
column4: captured German soldiers were held at the camp.

column1: === Post-colonial period ===
In January 2012
column2: Laghouat was the site of anti-government protests over improper housing
column4: and treatment of the elderly by police.  The police used tear gas to disperse the protesters.

column1: == Arts and culture ==
Laghouat has a long tradition as a meeting place and cultural center
column2: and has developed handicrafts based around the local raw materials.

column1: In modern times
column2: sand blasting art has emerged in Laghouat. Al-Taher Jadid is a local master of the form.

column1: == Tourism ==
The province has sought to develop tourism with new 4-star hotels
column2: though the existing hotels in Laghouat do not exceed the 3-star rating.

column1: The region is known for its variety of landscapes – mountain valleys
column2: plateaus
column4: sand dunes and steppes – within a small area.  Some call it the city of the four seasons
column5: due to the diversity of the terrain.

column1: Landmarks of the town include the old mosque
column2: the fortress of Sidi El Hajj Issa

column1: The French colonial military fort Tizgraren Tower (also called Buskaran Tower) was opened as a tourist attraction in 2011. It is located at the highest point in the town and dates to 1857. It has four wings
column2: catacombs
column3: and a large square containing the tomb of General Buskaran
column4: who was assassinated within the fort. In the last years of colonization
column5: the tower was converted from a barracks to a military hospital specialized in treating respiratory conditions and allergies. Following Algerian independence
column6: it was used by various security departments.
